text: (bouncy music)
- Hey football fans.
I'm Cynthia Frelund

and welcome to the NFL's
fourth annual Big Data Bowl
powered by AWS.

Our next team of finalists
are graduate students

at Simon Fraser University
in Vancouver, Canada,
who developed a framework for identifying

and comparing the best
punt returners in the NFL.

Say hello to Robyn,
Brendan, Ryker and Elijah.
- Our team is Robyn Ritchie, Ryker Moreau,
Brendan Kamugai, and Elijah Cavan.
We're a group of graduate students

at Simon Fraser University
in Vancouver, Canada.
Our Big Data Bowl entry is "Punt Returns:
"Using the Math to Find a Path"

where we look to improve
a punt returner's ability
to gain yards on a play.

Today, we have chosen to
show how our work can help

the Kansas City Chiefs elevate
their punt return performance
through a mixture of video review,
data visualization, and novel metrics.
In 2018, the Chief's ranked third
in average yard per return,
but dropped to 26 and 2020.
We will focus on Mecole Hardman
and his role as the lead punt returner
in both 2019 and 2020.
Hardman has all the physical tools
to be a top punt returner in the NFL.

So what has caused the
Chiefs punt return unit
to struggle in recent years?

To motivate, here's a clip
from the 2020 week 12 matchup
between the Chiefs and Buccaneers.
Hardman completes a five yard return
attempting to stretch the field
by breaking contain with his speed.
We will dive deeper into this play
by showing what Hardman may have missed
and evaluate his decision making
over the course of the return.
- Our goal is to determine
the optimal route to the end zone.

We look to find gaps that
the returner can exploit

by quantifying field
pressure using a metric

for the penalized expected
arrival times of the opponents.
To do this,

we make thousands of
calculations at every frame.
Finally, we adapt the A* algorithm,

which connects the dots
between the actionable gaps
and finds the path that would help

the returner gain as
many yards as possible.
Once we have this optimal path,

we use a metric called
the Frechet Path Deviation
to quantify the difference
between the optimal and observed paths.
This is used to evaluate
the plant returner's decision making,
and next will be used as a novel metric
in our conditional density model,

which predicts the expected
yards remaining on the play.

This metric, along with blocker
leverages and convex holes
that quantify field control are among
the key inputs in our model,
which associates a probability
to each potential ending yard line.

We then use this
distribution from our model

to evaluate returns
through our final metric

called the return yards
above expected, or RYAE.
These methods allow us to quantify both
how successful a return was
and the reason behind the success.
- Back to our original clip.
Let's see how Hardman performed
compared to our optimal path.
At the moment Hardman receives the punt,
he's standing on the five yard line.
Given the current situation,

our model predicts Hardman
will make a 15 yard return.
Notice that in this moment,

Hardman has three well
blocks in front of him,
as well as a fourth blocker
that's set up to seal the gap.
Our algorithm takes these into account

to find the safest path through
the kick team's coverage.
Throughout the play,

Hardman disregards all gaps
and blocks moving laterally

and hopes he can beat his
opponents to the outside.
In the end, Hardman gains five yards
with an initial expectation of 15.
Averaged over the play,
he achieved nine yards below our estimate.

- Let's move on to a more broad
overview of the 2020 season
and see how Hardman compares
to our other star punt returners.
Our model places Hardman at 15,

well behind players like
Olszewski, Harris, and Renfrow.

Notice that Hardman is
the only player here
with a negative RYAE per play.
And furthermore, he's only achieving
about 25% of his expected yards.

Here's a graph comparing
yards gained per play
with the average path deviation.
Based on our results,

Hardman can improve his
yards gained per play

by better considering
his available options,
improving his ability to find gaps

and blocks available will
help to bring him closer
to these other key returners.
Placing these four punt returners paths
on the same starting line,

Hardman uses his speed to
stretch the field laterally

compared to other stars who
tend to return more vertically.

Although his paths tend
to avoid heavy contact,
it's unlikely this strategy will result
in a successful return.
Now let's contrast our optimal path
with Hardman's observed path.
On the left are returns

where Hardman's path
deviations are the largest

and his returns are
well below expectations.
Compare these to the plays on the right
where his path deviation is small.

Here, he uses his blocks to
increase his upfield movement

completing a near perfect
return according to our model.

- The Chiefs special teams
coordinator reiterated this
when he spoke of Hardman's performance
after a recent playoff win.

He stated that "he ran tough,
he didn't run outta bounds,
he actually cut back into the field,"

noting that he had his
best punt return day
since he's been with the Chiefs.

This is quite different from
Hardman's typical strategy
and we believe that our tools can be used

to ensure he has more
games similar to this one.
Consequently, this will improve
the Chief's field positioning
and lead to more points on that board.
Thank you for your time.
(bouncy music)
